  Mongolia’s  rapid  urbanization  in  the  late  20th  century  has  created  an 
urban  population  of  1.4  million  people  (about  58%  of  the  country’s 
total). As the capital, Ulaanbaatar, gained primacy in the last decade, it 
attracted  the  most  foreign  assistance,  to  the  detriment  of  balanced 
urban  and  regional  development.  About  40%  of  the  urban  population 
lives in the provincial capitals, which are expected to serve not only the 
towns  themselves  but  also  their  rural  hinterlands.  Because  of  the  lack 
of  funds  for  rehabilitation  and  periodic  maintenance,  urban  service 
infrastructure in these towns is seriously dilapidated and in urgent need 
of  repair.  Provincial  capitals  function  as  the  economic  centers  of  their 
rural  hinterlands,  as  most  of  the  agroprocessing  and  nonagricultural 
employment  in  the  provinces  is  located  there.  The  provincial  capitals 
need to improve their service coverage of the towns in their provinces 
so that they can function as sustainable regional economic centers as 
well as seasonal shelters for the rural population from the hinterlands.  
 
While  the  incidence  of  poverty  in  Ulaanbaatar  is  only  34%,  in  the 
project  towns  it  is  over  50%.  Moreover,  the  formal  areas  in  urban 
settlements, with their fully networked utilities, stand in sharp contrast to 
the  informal  ger  (traditional  circular  tent)  settlements  with  minimal 
services.  On  average,  46%  of  the  people  in  the  formal  areas  have 
connections to water supply, as opposed to very few in the ger areas. 
Waterborne  diseases  are  therefore  more  prevalent  in  informal  areas, 
and  children  in  the  ger  areas  are  twice  as  likely  to  have  diarrhea  and 
respiratory  infections.  The  high  incidence  of  poverty  and  poor  living 
standards  in  the  provincial  towns  strongly  suggest  that  poverty 
reduction programs should be targeted at the informal settlements, and 
that the present imbalance in the provision of urban services should be 
redressed in favor of the informal ger areas. 
 
Accordingly,  the  Government  of  Mongolia  is  seeking  to  improve  the

quality of life and to protect public health by rehabilitating and extending 
basic urban services, while strengthening the capacity of local PUSOs 
to  provide  and  operate  these  essential  services.  Following  the 
successful  implementation  of  the  Provincial  Towns  Basic  Urban 
Services  Project  financed  by  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  for 
five  provincial  capitals  in  western  Mongolia,  the  Government  is 
endeavoring to expand the project concept to other regions where living 
conditions and service functions are rapidly deteriorating. 
 
The long-term goals of the proposed Project are to (i) support balanced 
and  equitable  regional  development  by  promoting  viable  provincial 
urban  centers  that  can  provide  support  and  services  for  their  rural 
hinterlands; and (ii) reduce urban poverty and improve living conditions 
for  urban  residents  in  provincial  towns.  The  specific  objectives  of  the 
Project are to (i) improve basic urban services, (ii) reduce inequality in 
access  to  urban  services  between  the  formal  and  informal  areas,  and 
(iii)  strengthen  the  operation  and  management  capacities  of  local 
PUSOs  in  order  to  achieve  sustainable  regional  development  in  the 
eight provincial capitals of central and eastern Mongolia. 
 
The  project  comprises  two  parts:  Part  A,  Urban  Infrastructure  and 
Equipment,  covers  (i)  rehabilitation  of  the  centralized  water  supply 
systems and improvement of water distribution for residents of  informal 
areas;  (ii)  improvement  and  extension  of  sanitation  facilities,  including 
sewage treatment works; (iii) refurbishment and replacement of heating 
and  hot  water  supply  systems,  including  boilers  and  distribution  lines; 
(iv) provision of solid waste collection and management equipment; and 
(v) rehabilitation of public bathhouses and provision of new bathhouses 
to serve informal areas. Part B, Project Implementation and Institutional 
Development,  covers  (i)  project  management,  detailed  engineering 
design,  construction  supervision,  and  implementation  support;  and  (ii) 
institutional  capacity  building  programs  for  PUSOs,  including  (a)  a 
community participation and health education program, (b) a water loss 
reduction  program  and  training  in  operation  and  maintenance,  (c) 
training  in  financial  management  and  corporate  planning,  (d)  land  use 
planning and management, and (e) solid waste management planning 
and training. 
 
The Project will cost about $26.5 million equivalent, $13.3 million of this 
in foreign exchange costs and $13.2 million equivalent in local currency 
costs.

the winter months, when they shelter in the project towns. Residents of 
the  informal  settlement  areas  will  have  improved  access  to  water  and

I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

 
1. 
I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to  Mongolia  for  the  Integrated  Development  of  Basic  Urban  Services  in  Provincial  Towns 
Project. 
 

II. 

RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 

Performance Indicators and Analysis 

 
2. 
In  line  with  its  long-term  goals  for  the  urban  sector  of  promoting  balanced  regional 
development  and  improving  living  conditions,  the  Government  of  Mongolia  has  requested  the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) to assist in the integrated development of urban infrastructure 
and services in eight provincial capitals in the eastern and central regions.1 This Report is based 
on  the  findings  of  the  Fact-Finding  Mission,  discussions  with  national  and  local  government 
agencies  concerned,  and  talks  with  international  organizations.  The  project  framework  is  in 
Appendix 1, and the project processing chronology is in Appendix 2. 
 
A. 
 
3. 
Mongolia  urbanized  rapidly  in  the  second  half  of  the  20th  century,  and  the  trend 
accelerated  during  the  transition  from  a  centrally  planned  to  a  market-based  economy.  The 
urban population2 increased by 20%, to 1.4 million (about 58% of Mongolia’s total population of 
2.4 million), from 1990 to 2000.3 More than half of these live in the capital, Ulaanbaatar, while 
10%  live  in  the  three  cities  of  Darhan,  Erdenet,  and  Choir.  The  remaining  40%  live  in  18 
provincial  capitals,  or  aimag  centers,  with  an  average  population  of  25,000.  The  18  provinces 
are  further  divided  into  324  rural  districts  (soums),  and  each  soum  is  divided  into  smaller 
administrative  units  called  bags.  This  administrative  hierarchy  has  played  an  important  role  in 
government  administration  as  well  as  in  the  delivery  of  basic  services  to  the  widely  dispersed 
rural  population.  As  the  administrative  and  service  centers  of  the  provinces,  the  18  provincial 
capitals serve their own populations as well as the rural hinterlands. 
 
4. 
While all provincial capitals serve their respective provinces, some of the capitals have 
important regional roles. The meat-packing plants in Sainshand and Choibalsan, which export to 
Russia, serve livestock owners in a wide region covering most of the project provinces. Another 
project town, Dalandzadgad, is the center of tourism and cashmere production in the southern 
Gobi area. Prospects for oil and mineral exploitation are also creating demand for infrastructure 
services  in  other  provincial  centers.  The  provincial  capitals,  where  most  nonagricultural 
employment can be found, function as the economic centers of their rural hinterlands, and also 
link urban industrial processing activities with agricultural and raw material supplies. 
 
5. 
However,  infrastructure  for  urban  services  in  the  provincial  capitals  is  seriously 
dilapidated and in urgent need of repair and improvement. In the early 1980s, Mongolia began 
developing basic infrastructure and services in provincial capitals with financial assistance from 
the former Soviet Union (FSU). When the FSU collapsed, the program stopped; some towns in 
the  eastern  and  central  regions  ended  up  with  incompletely  installed  services.  At  the  end  of 
2000,  32%  of  the  urban  population  had  access  to  potable  water,  27%  to  district  heating,  and 
37%  to  waste  disposal  services.  Public  bathhouses,  largely  serving  informal  ger  (traditional

lack  of  funds  for  rehabilitation  and  periodic  maintenance  has  led  to  serious  deterioration  in

hinterlands.  Hence,  to  help  improving  the  productivity  of  the  urban  economy  and  to  sustain 
regional  service  functions,  basic  urban  services  such  as  heating  and  hot  water,  water  supply 
and  sanitation,  solid  waste  management,  and  bathhouses  in  provincial  capitals  must  be 
improved and delivered efficiently.  
 
6. 
In  the  past  decade,  Ulaanbaatar  has  attracted  most  of  the  foreign  investment  in  urban 
infrastructure  and  services  as  well  as  urban  migration,4  to  the  detriment  of  the  provincial 
capitals.  Other  than  ADB’s  investment  in  the  provincial  capitals  of  the  five  western  provinces5 
(para.  11),  there  has  been  little,  if  any,  investment  in  improving  urban  service  delivery  in  the 
provincial capitals. The Government’s regional development policy aims to remedy this situation 
by  encouraging  investment  in  the  provincial  capitals,  thereby  correcting  the  imbalance  in 
investment  between  Ulaanbaatar  and  the  provincial  centers,  while  at  the  same  time  achieving 
more balanced regional growth. 
 
7. 
A  second  level  of  imbalance  in  urban  investment  exists  within  the  provincial  capitals 
themselves.  Socialist  planning  led  to  a  separation  of  formal  apartment  and  institutional  areas 
from informal ger areas. Formal areas have, to varying degrees, centrally provided heating and 
hot  water;  water  supply  and  sanitation;  solid  waste  collection;  and  a  full  range  of  educational, 
health,  social,  and  commercial  facilities.  On  the  other  hand,  services  are  minimal  in  the 
supposedly  temporary  informal  ger  areas,  which  hold  at  least  half  of  the  population  of  the 
provincial  capitals.  In  ger  areas  water  tanks  supply  neighborhood  water  kiosks;  sanitation 
facilities take the form of on-plot pit latrines; and coal-, wood-, or dung-fired stoves are used for 
heating  and  cooking.  The  separation  of  the  two  communities  has  contributed  to  the 
development  of  towns  with  extensive  unused  open  space  and  low  densities,  making  service 
delivery  more  costly.  In  a  typical  provincial  capital,  46%  of  the  residents  in  formal  settlements 
have  connections  to  water  supply  versus  very  few  in  informal  areas.  Likewise,  households  in 
informal  areas  pay  significantly  more  for  heating,  water,  and  solid  waste  disposal.  Water 
consumption in the informal areas is low, typically 6–12 liters per capita per day, because the 
water  costs  up  to  20  times  as  much  as  that  supplied  to  apartment  residents.  Hence,  in  all 
provincial  capitals,  informal  area  residents  tend  to  subsidize  the  price  of  water  for  apartment 
dwellers.

B. 
 
An analysis of urban sector problems and constraints is presented in Appendix 3.9 A key 
9. 
constraint  on  the  provincial  capitals  is  the  lack  of  a  long-term  financing  mechanism  for  capital 
investment  and  sustainable  operation  and  maintenance  (O&M).  Since  the  withdrawal  of 
subsidies from the FSU, the sector has not attracted enough funds to stop the deterioration of 
infrastructure  and  urban  services.  Low  capacity  constrains  private  sector  participation  and 
improved service delivery through public-private partnerships. 
 
10. 
In addition, local public service organizations, for lack of financial and managerial skills 
suited  to  the  new  economic  situation,  have  not  been  able  to  optimize  the  provision  of  urban 
services.  The  institutional  structure,10  which  is  dominated  by  the  provincial  governments,  has 
worsened  the  situation.  The  incomes  of  the  public  utility  companies  have  been  effectively 
controlled  by  the  provincial  governors,  but  it  is  not  clearly  defined  what  kinds  of  financial 
oversight or responsibilities of the utilities are exercised by the local government. In 1997, the 
Government  initiated  the  establishment  of  public  urban  services  organizations  (PUSOs)  to 
provide  water  and  sewerage,  and,  in  many  cases,  apartment  maintenance,  solid  waste 
collection,  and  public  bathhouses  under  one  organization  for  delivery  efficiency.  However,  in 
most provincial capitals, the PUSOs still operate as departments of the provincial governments, 
reporting principally to the provincial governor, and are thus limited in delivering urban services 
efficiently based on commercial principles. 
 
11. 
To  address  these  concerns,  ADB  in  1997  approved  the  Provincial  Towns  Basic  Urban 
Services  (PTBUS)  Project  (footnote  5),  the  implementation  of  which  in  the  five  western 
provincial  capitals11  has  given  clear  direction  to  urban  management  policy  and  coherence  in 
institutional,  technical,  and  financial  conditions.  Notably,  in  contrast  to  the  other  13  provincial 
capitals,  where  population  has  decreased,  the  five  western  provincial  capitals  have  added  to 
their  population  over  the  implementation  period.  Their  PUSOs  have  also  acquired  critical 
knowledge and management skills. To make the other PUSOs more independent and financially 
sustainable,  the  Government  is  striving  to  introduce  market-based  management  in  their 
provincial  capitals.  At  the  same  time,  the  Government  learned  from  the  PTBUS  Project  that  it 
would  be  more  efficient  to  include  district  heating  as  one  of  the  PUSO’s  service  delivery 
components,  and  tariff  adjustments  should  be  enforced  within  consumers’  affordability  and 
based on cost-recovery principles.  
 
12.

Special Features 

1. 

Appropriate Technologies 

 
28. 
The Project will follow a least-cost approach to providing the required interventions and 
improvements  in  basic  urban  services.  Existing  systems  will  be  rehabilitated,  instead  of  new 
ones being built, to keep the costs low so that tariffs remain affordable to end users. The use of 
local materials and labor-intensive approaches was given priority in choosing among alternative 
options.  Water  supply  rehabilitation  will  help  provide  more  reliable  service  and  produce 
quantitative as well as qualitative improvements in hygiene and health. In particular, extending

water  consumption  by  low-income  households.  Given  the  cold  weather,  the  construction  of 
oxidation ponds in place of the dilapidated sewage plants has been adopted as a cost-effective 
and  appropriate  technology.  The  district  heating  and  hot  water  supply  components  will  largely 
replace  dilapidated  old  pumps  and  outdated  hotwater  heat  exchangers.  The  Project  will  also 
provide  for  the  development  of  proper  landfill  planning  and  management  skills,  using  locally 
available, low-cost materials and approaches. Overall, the Project will promote investments that 
are cost-effective and simple to operate and maintain in the context of technologies suitable for 
the harsh winters in the country. 
 

2. 

Corporatization of PUSOs 

 
29. 
The  Project,  through  the  proposed  institutional  development  program,  will  help  the 
PUSOs  become  state-owned  limited  liability  companies,  in  conformity  with  Mongolia’s  1999 
Company  Law.  The  PUSOs  are  responsible  for  water  supply,  sewerage  systems,  apartment 
maintenance,  public  baths,  district  heating  and  hot  water  supply,  and  in  some  cases  the 
management of state-owned hotels. It has been agreed with the Government that the PUSOs in 
the  project  towns  will  be  organized  to  develop,  provide,  and  operate  services  in  the  following 
subsectors:  water  for  both  ger  areas  and  apartments,  sewerage,  public  baths,  solid  waste 
management,  and  district  heating  and  hot  water.  The  corporatization  of  the  PUSOs  through 
formal articles of association will provide legal definition for their services and integrate the five 
basic urban services subsectors. The five PUSOs in the western provincial centers covered by 
the  PTBUS  Project  were  corporatized  in  1999,  and  the  Government,  through  the  Ministry  of 
Infrastructure (MOI), is committed to extending this organizational structure to the PUSOs in the 
eastern and central regions.

Cost Recovery and Subsidy 

 
33. 
An important objective of the Project is to assist the PUSOs in generating more revenue 
from  their  own  sources  and  to  ensure  that  administration,  O&M,  and  capital  costs  are 
adequately covered. Tariffs will be increased so that PUSOs can meet their full cost recovery, 
taking  into  account  O&M,  capital  investment  costs  and  debt  service  obligations.  At  the  same 
time, the proposed tariff increase will always be below the generally accepted rule of household 
affordability, less than 6% of monthly income for water and sanitation, for example. To enhance 
the  poverty  impact  of  the  Project  and  reverse  the  regressive  subsidies  to  apartment  dwellers, 
tariff  cross-subsidies  have  been  targeted  to  informal  ger  areas,  where  the  percentage  of

water, sanitation, solid waste collection, and bathhouses will not increase until 2006 and have 
been  kept  constant  in  2002  prices.  The  targeted  internal  cross-subsidies  will  enhance  health

demonstration  components  will  be  implemented  initially  only  in  Ulaanbaatar,  the  bathhouse, 
briquette making, and greenhouse components will be implemented in the Project’s eight towns.

at the center, etc.); (v) select bathhouses to be integrated into the apartment service system to 
make  water,  heating,  and  sewage  connections  available;  (vi)  generate  more  revenue  by 
extending bathhouse services to include other services such as laundries, small workshops, and 
small shops; and (vii) introduce social pricing based on a social service card registration system, 
which will ensure both poverty targeting and higher revenue generation.

53. 
The  Project  is  expected  to  have  a  high  level  of  community  involvement  in  design  and

where  the  concentration  of  poverty  is  at  its  highest  in  Mongolia,  will  benefit  from  improved

exceed the generally accepted norm of 6% of monthly expenditure. Significantly, the proposed

channel the concessionality of the funds to the end beneficiaries, allowing the PUSOs to keep 
tariff  increases  minimal,  financially  viable,  and  affordable  to  end  users  at  the  same  time. 
Therefore, the low relending rate will be applied to some extent as an implicit subsidy to the end

that  will  result  from  increased  access  to  water  supply  as  well  as  individual  water  supply  and 
sewerage connections in some informal areas, (ii) the high priority of informal area households 
for  improved  solid  waste  collection  and  more  bathhouses,  and  (iii)  the  improvements  in 
environmental  cleanliness  and  therefore  in  health  and  productivity  among  informal  area 
households.  While  cross-subsidies  between  consumer  groups  are  extensive,  those  between 
subproject components are limited, and exist mainly for bathhouses, all of which are located in 
informal  ger  areas.  Funds  required  to  cross-subsidize  water,  solid  waste,  and  bathhouse 
services  to  informal  areas  will  come  primarily  from  heating,  hot  water,  water  supply  and 
sanitation  charges  imposed  on  organizations  and  apartment  dwellers.  According  to  PUSO 
financial projections, sufficient surpluses will be generated to cover the subsidies. Following the 
social pricing concept, it should be possible to recover a substantial portion of the costs from the

The economic evaluation of the water supply component is based on the benefits from 
(i)  improved  quality  of  nonincremental  water  supply  to  apartments  and  organizations,  and  (ii) 
incremental  water  supply  to  informal  area  households  and  newly  developed  plots.  The  water 
supply improvements comprise benefits to public and commercial organizations and households 
with connections and to households in informal areas that will have connections or will benefit 
from  improved  supply  to  local  water  kiosks.  Public  buildings  and  apartment  households  now 
connected  to  the  central  system  will  benefit  under  the  Project  from  improved  quality  and 
reliability of piped water. Households in informal areas with new connections and those that still 
obtain  water  from  kiosks  will  benefit  from  the  quantity  of  incremental  water  resulting  from  the 
higher level of service. The economic evaluation indicates that the water supply components in 
three  towns—Choibalsan,  Dalandzadgad,  and  Sainshand—have  a  highly  satisfactory  EIRR 
ranging from 46.3% in Choibalsan to 56.2% in Dalandzadgad. These are the three towns where 
the  water  supply  is  most  efficient,  and  the  economic  value  of  both  the  nonincremental  and 
incremental  water  volume  is  quite  high.  While  the  EIRRs  are  lower  in  the  other  towns,  they 
remain well above the economic opportunity cost of capital (EOCC) of 12%. Sensitivity analysis 
indicates that EIRRs are robust with respect to changes in costs and benefits, though they are 
marginally  more  sensitive  to  a  decrease  in  benefits.  In  general,  benefits  have  to  be  reduced 
significantly (ranging from 10% in Bulgan to 55% in Dalandzadgad) to push the EIRR below the 
12% EOCC level. 
 
64. 
The  economic  viability  of  the  district  heating  and  hot  water  supply  component  was 
analyzed  on  the  basis  of  (i)  the  economic  value  of  incremental  heat  supply,  estimated  as 
consumers’  willingness  to  pay  for  improved  heating  service;  and  (ii)  economic  cost  savings 
resulting from reduced losses of heat and hot water. EIRRs range from 23% to 58%, all above 
the  EOCC  of  12%.  The  results  of  sensitivity  analysis  indicate  that  the  economic  viability  of 
district heating with hot water in general is slightly sensitive to a reduction in benefits, compared 
with  cost  increases.  However,  benefits  have  to  be  reduced  substantially  (from  31%  to  91%) 
before EIRRs fall down to the EOCC level of 12%. 

 
65. 
The  sanitation  improvement,  solid  waste  management,  and  bathhouse  components  of 
the Project have been selected on a least-cost basis. The benefits of these components relate 
primarily  to  health,  environment,  and  poverty  reduction,  and  as  such,  were  assessed  in 
qualitative  terms.  Since  the  economic  cost  of  project  components  is  uniformly  less  than  the 
financial  cost  (adjusting  for  taxes),  the  results  of  the  financial  assessment  of  the  project 
components provide an indication of their lower-bound estimates of economic merit. In addition, 
since  all  components  will  have  positive  health  and  environmental  externalities,  they  are 
expected to add substantial benefits from the improvement in public health through a reduction 
in  typhus,  diarrhea,  and  skin  diseases  such  as  scabies  resulting  from  (i)  an  increase  in  the 
quantity of water consumed by the informal area residents, (ii) an improvement in the quality of 
water,  and  (iii)  an  improvement  in  the  health  of  children  in  the  informal  areas  because  of  the 
reduced  burden  and  energy  consumption  for  the  collection  of  water.  Several  unquantifiable 
economic  benefits  of  the  Project  are  difficult  to  capture  in  the  analysis.  These  include  (i) 
improvements in the environment because of the improved wastewater treatment and disposal 
of urban waste, (ii) improvements in the quality of urban life resulting from more reliable urban 
services,  (iii)  increased  opportunities  for  local  enterprise  and  employment  through  the 
community-type bathhouse facilities, and (iv) the use of labor-intensive construction methods for 
project implementation to stimulate and support the economies of the towns and hinterlands.

Project Risks 

 
D. 
 
66. 
The main risks associated with the Project are (i) Government fiscal constraints, which 
may  limit  the  availability  of  counterpart  funds;  (ii)  logistical  difficulties  associated  with  the  long 
distances  from  the  capital  city  and  between  the  towns,  which  would  increase  transportation 
costs;  (iii)  the  reluctance  of  provincial  governments  to  relinquish  sufficient  autonomy  to  the 
PUSOs to increase tariffs as necessary; and (iv) the limited institutional and financial capacities 
of  the  local  governments  and  PUSOs  to  sustain  the  Project.  The  first  constraint  is  general  to 
Mongolia  and  is  not  Project-specific.  However,  this  risk  has  been  addressed  by  keeping  the 
project  intervention  in  each  town  small  in  size,  thus  reducing  the  financial  demands  for  its 
implementation.  The  potential  logistical  difficulties  of  the  Project  have  been  minimized  by 
selecting towns that form circular patterns outside the hinterland boundary of Ulaanbaatar in the 
eastern  and  central  sections  of  the  country.  Local  governments  in  each  town  have  also 
demonstrated a high commitment to the Project. Through the corporatization of the PUSOs and 
increased  financial  independence,  an  arm’s-length  relationship  will  be  developed  between  the 
PUSOs  and  their  provincial  governments.  Financial  discipline  has  been  introduced  in  the 
PUSOs by requiring them to borrow funds to implement infrastructure improvements. They must 
sustain  their  financial  performance  to  successfully  service  the  debt.  To  this  end,  commitment 
toward  tariff  increases  during  project  implementation  has  been  obtained  from  the  PUSOs  and 
their  provincial  governments.  The  institutional  development  component  is  also  geared  toward 
making  PUSO  activities  financially  and  technically  sustainable.  The  limited  experience  of  the 
PMO and PIUs in project implementation and supervision has been addressed by providing for 
consulting  assistance  in  implementation.  Experienced  personnel  and  lessons  learned  in  the 
implementation of PTBUS Project will also benefit project implementation. The project PMO and 
PSC have been established to help minimize potential delays in Project startup.

contributing balanced regional development, creating short-term employment opportunities for the poor,

2. 
About  40%  of  the  urban  population  live  in  18  provincial  capitals  or  aimag  centers.  Provincial 
capitals function not only as the administrative service centers but also as the economic focuses of their 
rural  hinterlands,  as  most  of  the  non-agricultural  employment  in  the  provinces  is  located  there.  To 
generate  maximum  benefits  and  increase  the  productivity  of  the  urban  population,  efficient  delivery  of 
basic  urban  services,  such  as  heating  and  hot  water,  water  and  sanitation,  solid  waste  management, 
and bathhouses, is an essential condition. However, in the past decade, Ulaanbaatar has attracted most 
of  the  foreign  investment  in  urban  infrastructure  and  services  to  the  detriment  of  the  aimag  centers. 
Urban  services  in  the  provincial  capitals  are  seriously  dilapidated  and  in  urgent  need  of  repair  and 
improvement.  
 
3. 
Poverty means more than lack of adequate income, and involves multidimensional aspects. For 
poverty reduction, the Project aims to improve the quality of living standard, while redressing two levels 
of  imbalance:  (i)  unequal  regional  development  between  Ulaanbataar  and  provincial  capitals,  and  (ii) 
unequal  access  of  basic  urban  services  by  the  poor  living  in  informal  ger  areas.  For  the  former,  the

of the basic urban services to the informal ger areas where poverty incidence is likely to be twice as high 
as in the formal residence areas, and (ii) tariff reform to lower service charges to affordable levels for the

1. 
Financial internal rates of return (FIRRs) and economic internal rates of return (EIRRs) 
and fund flow projections have been prepared in accordance with the Asian Development Bank 
(ADB) Framework for Economic and Financial Appraisal of Urban Development Sector Projects 
and Guidelines for the Financial Governance and Management of Investment Projects Financed 
by the Asian Development Bank. In addition, economic analysis has been conducted following 
ADB Guidelines for the Economic Analysis of Water Supply Projects. The main objective of the 
evaluation  is  to  determine  various  aspects  of  financial  and  economic  feasibility  of  the 
subprojects in each town.  
 
B. 
 
2. 
FIRRs  have  been  prepared  for  the  integrated  subprojects  in  each  project  town 
comprising  heating  and  hot  water,  water  supply  and  sanitation,  solid  waste  management,  and 
bathhouse  components.  The  analysis  has  been  carried  out  using  projected  public  urban 
services organization (PUSO) finances, with and without the Project, up to 2017, i.e., 10 years 
after assumed project completion. In most cases, 3 years, 1999-2001, have been used as the 
base years, as before that time reliable records do not exist for the various entities, which were 
merged to become the present day PUSOs. The analysis is expressed in constant 2002 prices 
and  is  based  on  (i)  the  estimated  cost  of  the  Project  components  inclusive  of  operation  and 
maintenance  (O&M)  and  depreciation;  (ii)  implementation  over  the  period  2003-2007;  (iii) 
projections  of  operating  revenues  and  costs,  with  and  without  the  Project;  and  (iv)  a  real 
weighted average cost of capital of 2.5% for the Project. With-Project assumptions are based on 
enhanced  revenues  due  to  increased  tariffs  for  public  and  commercial  buildings  and 
apartments, as well as the savings that will occur to overall service production as a result of the 
Project. Tariff for informal (ger) areas have been kept constant in 2002 prices, while increases 
for commercial/public buildings and apartments have been kept as low as possible to maintain 
affordability  and  enhance  political  and  consumer  acceptance.  Details  of  subproject  and 
individual  component  FIRR  calculations  are  contained  in  Supplementary  Appendix  F  and 
Appendix 5 of the Town Feasibility Studies. 
 
3. 
Overall,  the  integrated  FIRRs  are  adequate  in  spite  of  the  minimal  increase  in  tariffs 
required  to  maintain  affordability.  The  base  case  FIRRs  in  the  eight  project  towns  vary  from 
6.2% in Sainshand to 3.6% in Dalandzadgad, which are above the real weighted average cost 
of capital of 2.5%. They are the lowest in Dalandzadgad as heating and hot water services are 
provided  by  a  state-owned  power  company,  the  power  plant  of  which  also  supplies  district 
heating  to  the  town.  FIRRs  are  high  for  Baruun-Urt  and  Sainshand,  as  heating  and  hot  water 
supply  the  majority  of  revenue  for  these  PUSOs.  Mainly  due  to  the  minimal  level  of  tariff 
increases,  the  FIRRs  are  sensitive  to  declines  in  operating  revenues.  The  FIRRs  of  individual 
components in each town all exceed 4%. Although the analysis of the individual subcomponents 
shows  that  they  are  quite  viable  on  their  own,  the  Project  will  be  investing  in  the  integrated 
services of the PUSOs and not in individual subcomponents.
